courses.name: Clinica ed etica di fine vita

publications.description:
Introduction
Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) represents a great challenge due to high mortality rate and severe permanent disability among survivors. The latest international guidelines stress therapeutic hypothermia (TH) (32°C-34°C) as the only neuroprotective treatment for comatose survivors.
Objective
Controlled normothermia at 37°C (CN) was applied, avoiding fever and temperature fluctuation. The aim is to demonstrate the safety and efficacy of CN, as compared with standard TH.
Patients and methods
This observational, perspective study included a total of 89 patients, admitted to our ICU between January 2012 and July 2014: 50 treated with TH (control group) and 39 maintained at 37°C (interventional group). The primary outcomes are survival and neurologic function at discharge. Length of ICU stay and number of complications represent- ed secondary outcomes.
Results
Control and interventional groups were similar. The study showed that 50% of the patients in the 33°C group has survived, as compared with 54% in the 37°C group (OR 33°C group, 1,167; CI-95%: 0,504-2,699; P =0,719). By the neurological point of view, 76% of the patients in the 33°C group had a good neurologic function, as compared with 81% in the 37°C group (OR 33°C group, 1,342; CI-95% 0,323-5,577; P =0,686). The analysis of secondary outcomes shows a significant re- duction in the number of complications in the 37°C group (OR 33°C group, 4,25; CI-95% 1,23-14,63; P=0,022).
Conclusion
In this study the maintenance at 33°C of OHCA unconscious survivors did not confer any benefit. We suggest that the implementation of CN in the clinical practice is safety and not inferior to TH.
publications.name: To cool or too cold, that is the question

publications.description: Accurate classification of nonsmall cell lung cancers is of paramount clinical relevance, as novel chemotherapeutic agents show different efficacy in adenocarcinomas (ADCs) compared with squamous cell carcinomas (SQCCs). Cyto and histomorphology may sometimes be insufficient for this distinction and immunohistochemistry may improve diagnostic accuracy. The measurement of miR-205 may be another tool for the distinction between ADC and SQCC. The aim of our study was to compare morphologic and immunohistochemical classification with the relative quantification of miR-205 and miR-21 insurgically resected and well-characterized lung tumors (25 ADCs, 24 SQCCs, 1 adenosquamous). The miR-21 relative levels were similar in SQCC and ADC, whereas the miR-205 relative levels were lower in ADC (P<0.0001). The miR-205 sample score value, determined according to Lebanony et al, was higher in ADC (range, 2.8 to 9.08) compared with SQCC (range, -4.17 to 2.445) (P<0.0001). Accordingly, 22 tumors were classified as ADC and 28 tumors as SQCC, although 8 cases (2 SQCCs and 6 ADCs) were in the range of "near cutoff values." Four cases classified as SQCC (according to the sample score method) corresponded to cases classified as ADC on the basis of morphoimmunohistochemical evaluation. In conclusion, the relative quantification of miR-205 and miR-21 seems to be a promising diagnostic tool. However, the molecular approach is still not completely satisfactory as it may misclassify a non-negligible percentage of cases. Therefore, it cannot be used as a substitute of accurate morphologic and immunophenotypical characterization of tumors, but could be used as an adjunctive diagnostic criterion in selected cases.
publications.name: miR-205 Expression levels in nonsmall cell lung cancer do not always distinguish adenocarcinomas from squamous cell carcinomas.
publications.publisher: Am. Journal of Surgical Pathology, 2011 Feb;35(2):268-75.

publications.description:
Large cell carcinoma (LCC) of the lung are heterogeneous and may be of different cell lineage. We analyzed 56 surgically resected lung tumors, classified as LCC on basis of pure morphological grounds, using a panel of immunophenotypic
markers (TTF-1, citokeratin 7, napsin A; SQCC, p63, cytokeratin 5, desmocollin 3 and ?np63) and the quantitative analysis of miR-205 (mi-R sample score method, mRSS). Based on immunoprofiles 19 (34%) cases were re-classified as adenocarcinomas (ADC), 14 (25%) as squamous cell carcinomas (SQCC), and 23 (41%) cases were unclassifiable. Of these 23 cases, 18 were classified as ADC and 5 as SQCC according to mRSS. Our data show that an extended panel of immunohistochemical markers, can re-classified around 60% of LCC as ADC or SQCC. However a relevant percentage of LCC may escape convincing immunohistochemical classification, and mRSS could be used for further typing, but its clinical relevance needs further confirmation.
publications.name: Heterogeneity of large cell carcinoma of the lung: an immunophenotypic and miRNA based analysis.

📣Breaking news📣
🫀Sei un giovane ricercatore under 35? 🚨Sei un senior e nel tuo gruppo un giovane promettente aspetta la sua occasione per farsi conoscere? Non perdete il secondo bando #IRCYoung in occasione del trentesimo compleanno di IRC! Il bando al link https://lnkd.in/djPgnnpd
Candidature entro il 30 luglio! 🗓️

Are you an Italian under 35 researcher? Your topic are cardiac arrest, trauma and emergency medicine? We’re waiting you! #IRCYoung! Here the open call https://lnkd.in/djPgnnpd
Deadline 30th of July!

Bastano poche semplici azioni per implementare nella pratica clinica una valutazione pre-dimissione e un follow up dopo arresto cardiaco! Il primo passo è immaginarlo, il secondo è iniziare e sperimentare che si può fare!
Grazie a Marco Mion per l’ispirante chiacchierata, ora online nel sesto episodio di #IRCTalks il podcast di Italian Resuscitation Council (IRC)!

Grazie ad Alberto Cucino, all'Italian Resuscitation Council (IRC) e all' Italian Resuscitation Council Foundation (IRC Foundation) per questa #IRCtalk sull'importanza (e, tutto sommato, la semplicità) di creare un sistema di follow-up per i pazienti sopravvissuti ad un arresto cardiaco e per i loro famigliari.
Per riassumere in poche parole....

✅ Prima della dimissione, valutare lo stato cognitivo, fisico ed emotivo del paziente. Infermieri, fisioterapisti, terapisti occupazioni e psicologi (lista non esaustiva) possono farlo in 30/60 minuti, previa una breve formazione;

✅ 1-3 mesi dopo la dimissione, appuntamento di follow-up - meglio di persona, ma può essere condotto anche al telefono o in videocall. Focus su vari aspetti (si vedano i link qui sotto), ma in particolare la prevenzione di ulteriori eventi,  il recupero fisico (inclusa valutazionel dell'affaticamento), cognitivo, del tono dell'umore e della qualità di vita. Se possibile, invitare anche un familiare e investigare anche il loro ritorno alla normalità. 
il tutto può essere fatto in un'ora, da infermieri/psicologi/fisioterapisti/etc (lista non esaustiva)

Se viene identificata qualche difficoltà significativa, inviare allo specialista più opportuno.

....i vantaggi? Moltissimi. I tre principali sono i seguenti:

✅Offrire un migliore servizio al paziente! Cura e riabilitazione, laddove necessarie, prima e dopo le dimissioni ospedaliere, sono parte integrale del processo di salvare una vita.
✅Migliorare gli outcome post-rianimazione (al di la della sopravvivenza e outcome neurologico)  - tra cui rientro al lavoro, reinserimento nella comunità, qualità della vita 
✅Permettere di raccogliere dati più dettagliati per meglio valutare l'efficacia di interventi neuro-protettivi (ma non solo) effettuati in fase acuta


La vita dopo un arresto cardiaco: come costruire un sistema di follow up

https://lnkd.in/e4C_CCqv

Grazie a SITI - ISIC per aver scelto Trento, a Giacomo Bellani per aver accolto la proposta e a Giuseppe Ristagno per l’eccellente programma scientifico! Grazie a tutti gli 80 partecipanti e gli oltre 20 relatori per due giorni di approfondimenti e workshop!
